BulletinMeasurements.avActivityHighlights: Wind slabs and gliding snow require caution.
BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment:
As a consequence of warming only isolated loose snow avalanches are possible, but they will be mostly small. In addition a substantial danger of gliding avalanches exists. This applies on steep east, south and west facing slopes below approximately 2400 m. Areas with glide cracks are to be avoided as far as possible.

The somewhat older wind slabs are in some cases still prone to triggering especially on very steep shady slopes above approximately 2400 m. These can especially at their margins be released by a single winter sport participant and reach medium size. The avalanche prone locations are easy to recognise. Caution is to be exercised in particular in gullies and bowls, and behind abrupt changes in the terrain.

Weak layers in the old snowpack can be released especially by large additional loads in particular at transitions from a shallow to a deep snowpack, when entering gullies and bowls for example. Avalanche prone locations are to be found on very steep shady slopes above approximately 2200 m. These places are very rare but are difficult to recognise. Avalanches can reach large size in isolated cases.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment: Wind slabs are lying on soft layers in particular on near-ridge shady slopes at high altitudes and in high Alpine regions. Sunshine and high temperatures will give rise as the day progresses to gradual moistening of the snowpack, in particular on steep sunny slopes. Faceted weak layers exist in the centre of the snowpack in particular above approximately 2200 m. This applies in particular on shady slopes.
BulletinMeasurements.tendencyComment: As a consequence of the occasionally strong northwesterly wind, fresh snow drift accumulations will form.

BulletinMeasurements.avActivityHighlights: The wind slabs of the last few days must be evaluated with care and prudence in high Alpine regions. Moist and wet avalanches are possible as a consequence of warming during the day and solar radiation.
BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment:
The wind slabs can be released, especially by large additional loads,. The avalanche prone locations are to be found in particular in gullies and bowls above approximately 2500 m and at transitions from a shallow to a deep snowpack.
In particular in steep rocky terrain and on very steep grassy slopes more medium-sized moist and wet avalanches are possible as a consequence of warming during the day. The avalanche prone locations for wet avalanches are to be found in particular below approximately 2300 m.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment: Fresh wind slabs have settled a little. Snow depths vary greatly at intermediate and high altitudes, depending on the infuence of the wind. Sunshine and high temperatures will give rise as the day progresses to increasing moistening of the snowpack in particular on sunny slopes at low and intermediate altitudes.

BulletinMeasurements.avActivityHighlights: The Avalanche Warning Service currently has only a small amount of information that has been collected in the field, so that the avalanche danger should be investigated especially thoroughly in the relevant locality.
BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment: The wind slabs of the last few days represent the main danger. The avalanche prone locations are to be found in particular adjacent to ridgelines and in gullies and bowls and in steep rocky terrain. As a consequence of warming, the likelihood of moist and wet avalanches being released will increase gradually in particular on steep sunny slopes. This applies even in case of a single winter sport participant in some cases.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment: The meteorological conditions will cause a weakening of the snowpack on steep sunny slopes.
BulletinMeasurements.tendencyComment: The weather will be very mild.

BulletinMeasurements.avActivityHighlights: The Avalanche Warning Service currently has only a small amount of information that has been collected in the field, so that the avalanche danger should be investigated especially thoroughly in the relevant locality.
BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment: The wind slabs of the last few days represent the main danger. The avalanche prone locations are to be found in particular adjacent to ridgelines and in gullies and bowls and in steep rocky terrain. As a consequence of warming, the likelihood of moist and wet avalanches being released will increase gradually in particular on steep sunny slopes. This applies even in case of a single winter sport participant in some cases.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment: The meteorological conditions will cause a weakening of the snowpack on steep sunny slopes.
BulletinMeasurements.tendencyComment: The weather will be very mild.

BulletinMeasurements.avActivityHighlights: The Avalanche Warning Service currently has only a small amount of information that has been collected in the field, so that the avalanche danger should be investigated especially thoroughly in the relevant locality.
BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment: The wind slabs of the last few days represent the main danger. The avalanche prone locations are to be found in particular adjacent to ridgelines and in gullies and bowls and in steep rocky terrain. As a consequence of warming, the likelihood of moist and wet avalanches being released will increase gradually in particular on steep sunny slopes, this applies in particular in case of a large load.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment: The meteorological conditions will cause a weakening of the snowpack on steep sunny slopes. In some regions from a snow sport perspective, in most cases insufficient snow is lying.
BulletinMeasurements.tendencyComment: The weather will be very mild.

BulletinMeasurements.avActivityHighlights: The Avalanche Warning Service currently has only a small amount of information that has been collected in the field, so that the avalanche danger should be investigated especially thoroughly in the relevant locality.
BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment: The wind slabs of the last few days represent the main danger. The avalanche prone locations are to be found in particular adjacent to ridgelines and in gullies and bowls and in steep rocky terrain. As a consequence of warming, the likelihood of moist and wet avalanches being released will increase gradually in particular on steep sunny slopes, this applies in particular in case of a large load.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment: The meteorological conditions will cause a weakening of the snowpack on steep sunny slopes. In some regions from a snow sport perspective, in most cases insufficient snow is lying.
BulletinMeasurements.tendencyComment: The weather will be very mild.

BulletinMeasurements.avActivityHighlights: Wind slabs require caution.
BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment:
The no longer entirely fresh wind slabs are in some cases still prone to triggering above approximately 2400 m. Wind slabs can in some places be released by a single winter sport participant and reach medium size. The avalanche prone locations are to be found in particular on very steep shady slopes. Caution is to be exercised in particular adjacent to ridgelines and in gullies and bowls.

Weak layers in the old snowpack can be released in very isolated cases in particular at transitions from a shallow to a deep snowpack, when entering gullies and bowls for example. This applies on very steep shady slopes above approximately 2400 m. The avalanche prone locations are very rare but are barely recognisable.

In addition as the day progresses on south facing slopes, very occasional mostly small loose snow avalanches are possible. In the regions with a lot of snow individual gliding avalanches are possible.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment:
The wind slabs are lying on soft layers in particular on shady slopes at elevated altitudes.
Faceted weak layers exist in the centre of the snowpack in particular above approximately 2400 m. Sunshine and high temperatures will give rise as the day progresses to slight moistening of the snowpack in particular on sunny slopes.
BulletinMeasurements.tendencyComment: As a consequence of the occasionally strong northwesterly wind, fresh snow drift accumulations will form.

BulletinMeasurements.avActivityHighlights: The wind slabs of the last few days represent the main danger. Moist and wet avalanches are possible as a consequence of warming.
BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment:
The fresh and somewhat older wind slabs can be released in particular on very steep north, east and southeast facing slopes. The avalanche prone locations are to be found in particular in gullies and bowls above approximately 2500 m and at transitions from a shallow to a deep snowpack. In some cases the avalanches are medium-sized and can mostly be released by large loads. In particular in high Alpine regions these avalanche prone locations are more prevalent.
In particular in steep rocky terrain and on very steep grassy slopes moist and wet avalanches are possible as a consequence of warming. The avalanche prone locations for wet avalanches are to be found in particular below approximately 2500 m.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment: Sunshine and high temperatures gave rise to gradual consolidation of the snowpack in particular at low and intermediate altitudes. Snow depths vary greatly at intermediate and high altitudes, depending on the infuence of the wind. At low altitude only a little snow is lying. Sunshine and high temperatures will give rise as the day progresses to increasing moistening of the snowpack in particular on sunny slopes above approximately 2500 m.

BulletinMeasurements.avActivityHighlights: The wind slabs represent the main danger. Slight increase in danger of moist and wet avalanches as a consequence of warming.
BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment:
Wind slabs can be released by large loads in particular, especially on very steep shady slopes above approximately 2600 m, and adjacent to ridgelines and in gullies and bowls.
Until the temperature falls more small and medium-sized moist loose snow avalanches are possible below approximately 3300 m. This applies on very steep sunny slopes, and in steep rocky terrain.
In particular on very steep grassy slopes individual small and medium-sized ground avalanches are possible between approximately 2400 and 2800 m, in particular on south and southwest facing slopes.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment:
Over a wide area there is more snow than usual, in particular above approximately 2200 m.
The strong wind has transported a lot of snow.
As a consequence of highly fluctuating temperatures and solar radiation a crust formed on the surface at the weekend. Very early morning: In steep terrain there is a danger of falling on the icy crust.
Sunshine and high temperatures will give rise as the day progresses to increasing moistening of the snowpack on very steep southeast, south and southwest facing slopes below approximately 3400 m.
Towards its base, the snowpack is largely stable.
In the last few days on very steep grassy slopes several medium-sized avalanches occurred naturally. This applies on south and southwest facing slopes.
BulletinMeasurements.tendencyComment: On Wednesday it will be cold. The danger of moist and wet avalanches will decrease quickly. The wind will be moderate to strong adjacent to ridgelines. The danger of dry slab avalanches will increase a little during the day.

BulletinMeasurements.avActivityHighlights: Wind slabs represent the main danger, especially along the border with France. Moist and wet avalanches are possible as a consequence of warming.
BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment: The more recent wind slabs can be released, especially by large additional loads, in particular on very steep shady slopes above approximately 2700 m. The avalanche prone locations are to be found in gullies and bowls and in the vicinity of peaks. In some places wind slabs are lying on an icy crust. Restraint should be exercised because avalanches can sweep people along and give rise to falls. In particular on very steep sunny slopes individual mostly small moist and wet avalanches are possible as a consequence of warming during the day.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment: Sunshine and high temperatures gave rise to gradual consolidation of the snowpack. Below approximately 2200 m from a snow sport perspective, in most cases insufficient snow is lying. Above approximately 2500 m snow depths vary greatly at intermediate and high altitudes, depending on the infuence of the wind. Sunshine and high temperatures will give rise as the day progresses to increasing moistening of the snowpack in particular on sunny slopes at intermediate and high altitudes.

BulletinMeasurements.avActivityHighlights: Wind slabs are to be evaluated with care and prudence.
BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment:
The wind slabs are to be evaluated with care and prudence in all aspects above approximately 2200 m. In some cases avalanches are medium-sized and can be released even by a single winter sport participant. As a consequence of warming, the likelihood of moist loose snow avalanches being released will increase a little in particular on very steep sunny slopes at intermediate and high altitudes. Caution is to be exercised in particular adjacent to ridgelines and in gullies and bowls.

Weak layers in the old snowpack can be released in very isolated cases by individual winter sport participants in particular at transitions from a shallow to a deep snowpack, when entering gullies and bowls for example. This applies in particular on very steep northwest, north and northeast facing slopes in particular above approximately 2400 m.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment:
Wind slabs are lying on soft layers in particular on shady slopes at elevated altitudes. The fresh and somewhat older wind slabs are mostly easy to recognise but can in some cases be released easily especially at their margins.

Faceted weak layers exist in the centre of the snowpack in particular above approximately 2400 m. Weak layers in the old snowpack are difficult to recognise.
BulletinMeasurements.tendencyComment: The weather conditions will foster a gradual settling of the snow drift accumulations. On Wednesday it will be cold.

BulletinMeasurements.avActivityHighlights: Slight increase in danger of moist and wet avalanches as a consequence of warming.
BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment:
As a consequence of a moderate to strong wind from westerly directions, wind slabs formed by Friday.
Such avalanche prone locations are to be found in particular adjacent to ridgelines and in gullies and bowls above approximately 2600 m and at transitions from a shallow to a deep snowpack. Avalanches can be released, mostly by large additional loads, especially on very steep slopes on shady slopes.
As a consequence of warming and solar radiation a low danger of moist and wet snow slides will be encountered in some regions, in particular on extreme sunny slopes, and in steep rocky terrain below approximately 3300 m.

Very early morning: In steep terrain there is a danger of falling on the icy crust.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment:
Above approximately 2200 m from a snow sport perspective, in most cases insufficient snow is lying. In particular in the regions neighbouring those that are subject to danger level 1 (low) a little snow is lying in all altitude zones.

Sunshine and high temperatures will give rise as the day progresses to increasing moistening of the snowpack on very steep southeast, south and southwest facing slopes below approximately 3400 m.
As a consequence of highly fluctuating temperatures and solar radiation a crust formed on the surface at the weekend.
Towards its base, the snowpack is largely stable.
BulletinMeasurements.tendencyComment: The danger of moist and wet avalanches will decrease quickly. The danger of dry slab avalanches will increase but remain within the current danger level.

BulletinMeasurements.avActivityHighlights: The wind slabs represent the main danger. As a consequence of warming there will be an increase in the danger of moist and wet avalanches.
BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment:
The wind slabs are to be evaluated with care and prudence in all aspects above approximately 2000 m. In some cases avalanches are medium-sized and can be released even by a single winter sport participant. As a consequence of warming, the likelihood of moist loose snow avalanches being released will increase a little in particular on very steep sunny slopes at intermediate and high altitudes. Caution is to be exercised in particular adjacent to ridgelines and in gullies and bowls.
Weak layers in the old snowpack can be released especially by large additional loads in particular on very steep shady slopes. This applies in particular on very steep northwest, north and northeast facing slopes in particular above approximately 2400 m.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment:
The fresh and somewhat older wind slabs are mostly easy to recognise but in some cases prone to triggering.
Faceted weak layers exist in the snowpack in particular on shady slopes. The surface of the snowpack will only just freeze and will already soften in the late morning.

BulletinMeasurements.avActivityHighlights: The visible wind slabs must be evaluated with care and prudence in particular on near-ridge shady slopes.
BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment: The new snow and wind slabs must be evaluated with care and prudence especially on north to northeast to northwest facing aspects. The avalanche prone locations are to be found in particular in north to northeast to northwest facing aspects and on wind-loaded slopes. Whumpfing sounds and the formation of shooting cracks when stepping on the snowpack serve as an alarm indicating the danger. As a consequence of warming individual small and, in isolated cases, medium-sized moist and wet avalanches are possible below approximately 2000 m.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment: The snowpack remains unfavourable in particular on steep shady slopes. Backcountry touring calls for experience in the assessment of avalanche danger.

BulletinMeasurements.avActivityHighlights: From a snow sport perspective, in most cases insufficient snow is lying. Isolated small moist and wet avalanches are possible as a consequence of warming.
BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment: Very early morning: Even in moderately steep terrain there is a danger of falling on the icy crust. In particular on very steep sunny slopes and at higher altitudes individual small moist and wet avalanches are possible as a consequence of warming.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment: In particular at low and intermediate altitudes hardly any snow is lying. Sunshine and high temperatures will give rise as the day progresses to increasing moistening of the snowpack in particular on sunny slopes at elevated altitudes.

BulletinMeasurements.avActivityHighlights: Low, level 1.
BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment: Thus far only isolated small avalanches are possible. The small wind slabs represent the main danger. The avalanche prone locations are to be found especially adjacent to ridgelines and in gullies and bowls above approximately 1800 m and on south and southwest facing slopes. In steep terrain there is a danger of falling on the hard crust.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment: The more recent wind slabs have formed adjacent to ridgelines and in gullies and bowls and generally in the high Alpine regions. They are very small and unlikely to be released now. As a consequence of highly fluctuating temperatures a crust will form on the surface.

BulletinMeasurements.avActivityHighlights: Wind slabs require caution.
BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment:
The wind slabs are in individual cases still prone to triggering in particular on very steep shady slopes above approximately 2400 m. The mostly small wind slabs are clearly recognisable to the trained eye. Caution is to be exercised in particular adjacent to ridgelines and in gullies and bowls.

In addition as the day progresses on south facing slopes, very occasional mostly small loose snow avalanches are possible.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment: The wind slabs are lying on soft layers in particular on shady slopes at elevated altitudes. Sunshine and high temperatures will give rise as the day progresses to slight moistening of the snowpack in particular on sunny slopes.
BulletinMeasurements.tendencyComment: As a consequence of the occasionally strong northwesterly wind, fresh snow drift accumulations will form.

BulletinMeasurements.avActivityHighlights: A generally favourable avalanche situation will prevail. Wet loose snow avalanches are possible.
BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment:
The wind slabs are small and can only be released in isolated cases. Individual avalanche prone locations are to be found in particular adjacent to ridgelines and in gullies and bowls, and behind abrupt changes in the terrain, especially on very steep shady slopes at elevated altitudes.
As a consequence of warming during the day and solar radiation individual wet loose snow avalanches are possible, but they will be mostly small. This applies on extremely steep sunny slopes.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment: Wind slabs are to be found in particular adjacent to ridgelines and in gullies and bowls. They are mostly small and unlikely to be released now. Sunshine and high temperatures will give rise as the day progresses to increasing moistening of the snowpack especially on sunny slopes. Snow depths vary greatly above the tree line, depending on the infuence of the wind.
BulletinMeasurements.tendencyComment: Moist and wet snow slides are still possible.

BulletinMeasurements.avActivityHighlights: The snowpack will be well bonded at low altitude.
BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment: The surface of the snowpack has frozen to form a strong crust and will soften during the day.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment: The old snowpack is well consolidated and its surface has a strong melt-freeze crust.

BulletinMeasurements.avActivityHighlights: From a snow sport perspective, in most cases insufficient snow is lying.
BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment: Very early morning: Even in moderately steep terrain there is a danger of falling on the icy crust.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment: In all altitude zones hardly any snow is lying.

BulletinMeasurements.avActivityHighlights: A generally favourable avalanche situation will prevail. Wet loose snow avalanches are possible.
BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment:
The wind slabs are small and can only be released in isolated cases. Individual avalanche prone locations are to be found in particular adjacent to ridgelines and in gullies and bowls, and behind abrupt changes in the terrain, especially on very steep shady slopes at elevated altitudes.
As a consequence of warming during the day and solar radiation individual wet loose snow avalanches are possible, but they will be mostly small. This applies on extremely steep sunny slopes.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment: Wind slabs are to be found in particular adjacent to ridgelines and in gullies and bowls. They are mostly small and unlikely to be released now. Sunshine and high temperatures will give rise as the day progresses to increasing moistening of the snowpack especially on sunny slopes. Snow depths vary greatly above the tree line, depending on the infuence of the wind.
BulletinMeasurements.tendencyComment: Moist and wet snow slides are still possible.

BulletinMeasurements.avActivityHighlights: From a snow sport perspective, in most cases insufficient snow is lying.
BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment: In particular on very steep sunny slopes and at higher altitudes individual small moist and wet avalanches are possible as a consequence of warming. The wind slabs are easy to recognise and can be released by large loads in particular.
BulletinMeasurements.tendencyComment: Moist and wet snow slides are still possible.
